p: The fundamental quantity regulating disease dynamics is the basic reproduction number (defined as R 0 = 〈 β〉/ γ, where 〈 β〉 is the average of β( t) over the year), which represents the average number of secondary infections in a fully susceptible population generated by a typical index case during the entire period of infectiousness. The larger the R 0, the higher the disease transmissibility. If R 0 > 1, the infection will be able to spread in a population. Otherwise, the infection will die out. For endemic diseases like measles, R 0 provides insights into the proportion p of population to be successfully vaccinated to achieve disease elimination; the equation p = 1–1/ R 0 is widely accepted (e.g., [ 5, 18, 20]). For instance, if R 0 = 10, at least 90% of children have to be routinely immunized to eliminate the disease.
